Subject files: Harrison Forman and Chairman Mao Tse-Tung [Zedong]

Harrison Forman with Chairman Mao Tse-Tung; Yenan, North China - 1944; Photo made during World War II when Harrison Forman was a War Correspondent based in Chungking, the wartime capital. Mr. Forman was the first American newsman invited to visit the regions controlled by the Chinese Communists in North China. His book, REPORT FROM RED CHINA, recounting his talks with the Red leaders, and travels with their troops in military actions against the Japanese, created a sensation when published in America. It was translated into fifteen foreign languages including Chinese

Verso: Harrison Forman with Chairman Mao Tse-Tung; Yenan, North China - 1944; Photo made during World War II when Harrison Forman was a War Correspondent based in Chungking, the wartime capital. Mr. Forman was the first American newsman invited to visit the regions controlled by the Chinese Communists in North China. His book, REPORT FROM RED CHINA, recounting his talks with the Red leaders, and travels with their troops in military actions against the Japanese, created a sensation when published in America. It was translated into fifteen foreign languages including Chinese

Subject files: French Legion of Honor

Note: Pictures made on May 5, 1938 when L. T. was made a Knight of the Legion of Honor by the French Government. Presentation made by French Ambassador, Count Rene Doynel de Saint-Quentin. The French Consul General, Chas de Fontnouvelle, was also present, and he is pictured here with L. T. and Saint-Quentin.
Mr. Lowell Thomas in May was decorated a Knight of the Legion of Honor by the French Ambassador

Stone from La Popa, famed convent in Cartagena, Colombia. Convent built following early discovery and was destroyed during pirate hold on the city in 16th century and earlier. Shot here is Marcia and Perry Weimer where the stone was selected atop the convent; Sent 1940 to Lowell

Note: Stone from La Popa, famed convent in Cartagena, Colombia. Convent built following early discovery and was destroyed during pirate hold on the city in 16th century and earlier. Shot here is Marcia and Perry Weimer where the stone was selected atop the convent; Sent 1940 to Lowell

Stone (square) from the ruins atop the famed Sachuaman Fortress in Cuzco, Peru. Effort to get this out was tremendous and only thru our mutal [sic] associations did the government allow this. I placed the stone in this position only for the photo. It had a rounded or semi square smaller rear side that indicated it may have been a $$$$$$ hinge or an anchor for whatever purpose. Shot here was made in November 1940 in Peru at the fortress. Marcia carried it in her coat until we returned to safety? it is one of a kind

Note: Stone (square) from the ruins atop the famed Sachuaman Fortress in Cuzco, Peru. Effort to get this out was tremendous and only thru our mutal [sic] associations did the government allow this. I placed the stone in this position only for the photo. It had a rounded or semi square smaller rear side that indicated it may have been a $$$$$$ hinge or an anchor for whatever purpose. Shot here was made in November 1940 in Peru at the fortress. Marcia carried it in her coat until we returned to safety? it is one of a kind

THEY PREPARE TO GET AHEAD: Stone Age savages of unexplored Sepik River area in New Guinea prepare for head-hunting battle against a rival tribe and make for a thrilling sequence in the first episode of the new television adventure series, "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be shown over the CBS television network on Tuesday, November 12, 8:00 to 9:00 P.M. EST. The series, which will consist of seven full-hour films in color of the adventures of Lowell Thomas and other explorers in such diverse places as New Guinea, the Arctic, Venezuela, the Australian Outback, and African desert and jungle, is being sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy divisions of General Motors. One film will be shown at specially-scheduled times once a month through May

EST. Stone Age savages of unexplored Sepik River area

SKILL FOR THE KILL; Lowell Thomas watches Stone Age head-hunter in unexplored New Guinea show skill with native bow and arrow during shooting in full color of the first episode in new adventure series, "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be shown over CBS television network on Tuesday, November 12, 8:00 to 9:00 P.M. EST. The savage tribesmen, who live exactly as they did 2,000 years ago and have no knowledge of common metals or other contrivances, depend on bow and arrow to kill rival neighbors for souvenir heads. According to the Thomas party, the natives' skill with the bow would make William Tell look like a rank amateur

Subject files: High Adventure with Lowell Thomas (North Pole)

ARCTIC PIONEERS REUNITE; New York, N. Y., August 31, 1957 - Four pioneers of Arctic exploration - Admiral Donald B. MacMillan, Sir Hubert Wilkins, Peter Freuchen and Col. Bernt Balchen - left Idlewild Airport with Lowell Thomas over the weekend on first step of a photography expedition to polar regions for new television adventure series, "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will make bow over CBS-TV network early in November. This is first meeting of quartet who will retrace trails in icy northern wastes which they pioneered and study new techniques of living in Arctic, which is now important American line of defense. (Left to right are shown: Adm. Donald B. MacMillan, Sir Hubert Wilkins, Peter Freuchen, Lowell Thomas, Col. Bernt Balchen and Gilbert Ralston.)

ARCTIC PIONEERS ON "HIGH ADVENTURE" DEC. 23; Arctic Pioneers Admiral Donald MacMillan, sole survivor of the first expedition to the North Pole in 1909; Col. Bernt Balchen, Arctic flyer; Lowell Thomas; and Sir Hubert Wilkins, who first tried to reach the Pole by submarine (shown here, left to right), will be seen on "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television, 10:00-11:00 PM, EST) Monday, December 23. ; As they help Thomas and his production crew navigate the icy trails of the Arctic, the pioneers of the polar regions relive High Adventure" themselves. Lowell Thomas, Jr. will produce the program

TWO FOR THE SHOW: Admiral Donald B. MacMillan (left) and Lowell Thomas discuss old-time Arctic adventure as they fly over the North Pole in the second episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be colorcast over the CBS-TV network Monday, December 23rd, 10:00-11:00 p.m., EST. Admiral MacMillan, who was a member of the Peary polar expedition in 1909 and was awarded a special Congressional medal for his efforts at that time, accompanied Thomas on his camera expedition to the frozen wastes. Other pioneer explorers Sir Hurbet Wilkins and Col. Bernt Balchen will be seen in "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy division of General Motors

FIND "HIGH ADVENTURE" IN ARCTIC AREAS: Col. Bernt Balchen, the first man to fly over the North and South poles, poses with Lowell Thomas at Elmendorf Air Base, Alaska, before filming of the second installment of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television, 10:00-11:00 PM, EST) Monday, December 23. Col. Balchen, who helps guide the Thomas expedition into the North Lands, is one of America's top aviation experts-- and like many others, is well aware of the strategic importance of Arctic bases for the air defense of the North American continent. In the above picture, the pair display their professional badge-- the flag of the Explorers' Club, the world-wide symbol of "High Adventure"

[press release] LOWELL THOMAS HITS ARCTIC TRAIL: The second installment of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television, 10:00- 11:00 PM, EST) Monday, December 23, will follow Thomas and his television band as they trek to "The Top of the World "-the North Pole. The program will visit America's northernmost air defenses-from Alaska's Cape Lisburne along the DEW line to the Greenland Ice Cap, where Mr. Thomas is seen in the above picture

LOWELL ON HIGH: Sitting practically on top of the world, Lowell Thomas poses for camera study during filming of second installment of his television adventure series, "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," above the Arctic Circle. Behind him is dome housing radar apparatus on so-called "Dew-Line" to warn our armed forces of the approach of unidentified aircraft. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy division of General Motors and will be telecast in full color for one hour over the CBS-TV network, Monday, December 23rd, 10:00-11:00 p.m., EST

"HIGH ADVENTURE" GOES FOR A SWIM-AT 60 DEGREES BELOW: "Come on in, the water's fine," one Navy Frogman might be saying to the other, in the second episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television, 10:00-11:00 PM, EST) Monday, December 23. When Lowell Thomas and his band of sourdoughs trek to the icy wasters of the Arctic they capture on film the heroic exploits of the dare-devil divers-the men of the Navy demolition squads who blast ice flows free with 18,000 pounds of TNT and keep America's vital supply lines along the Polar Sea open for shipping

VISITS ESKIMOS IN SECOND EPISODE OF "HIGH ADVENTURE," DEC. 23: Lowell Thomas, Jr. makes his television production debut as the producer of the Arctic chapter of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television, 10:00-11:00 PM, EST) Monday, December 23. Above, he visits an Eskimo family near Kotzebue, Alaska. All "armchair adventures" will see ancient tribal customs as these remote natives ten their nomadic reindeer herds in the far North. Other parts of the exciting program will show an Air Force scramble of F-89 Scorpion jets, as they battle mythical enemy planes; the radar warning posts of the distant DEW line and the Greenland Ice cap

READY TO GO-Lowell Thomas gets ready to direct camera operations at a huge taxidermy establishment in Kenya, Africa for a special sequence in the third episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be seen on the CBS television network Wednesday, January 22nd, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST. The hour-long color film will give TV-viewers a new insight into many corners of Africa which have never been photographed before. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy division of General Motors

CAMELS ARE COMING-Lowell Thomas gets into the act himself as he rides a camel during the filming of tough camel troops of the French army in the Sahara Desert outside of Timbuktu for "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be colorcast Wednesday, January 22nd, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST over the CBS television network. The third "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" in the monthly series sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy division of General Motors is devoted to the "heartline" of Africa from Timbuktu to Madagascar, via Kenya and Uganda

TAKES A BREATHER: Lowell Thomas takes time-out during the color filming of French native desert troops outside the ancient slave town of Timbuktu on the edge of the Sahara Desert for scenes in the third episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be shown on the CBS television network Wednesday, January 22nd, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST. These troops, mounted on camels, have the reputation of being the toughest in the world. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy division of General Motors

Subject files: High Adventure with Lowell Thomas (Tibet)

TALL GIFT: Lowell Thomas accepts ceremonial gift from Rimshi Dote, one of the Tibetan district governors, who is almost seven feet tall, enroute to Lhasa, the forbidden capital of Tibet. Thomas and his son, Lowell Thomas, Jr., were the 7th and 8th Americans allowed to visit that strange country which forms the basis of Episode No. 4 in the CBS television series, "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," (CBS-TV, Tuesday, February 25, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST)

Note: [press release] TALL GIFT: Lowell Thomas accepts ceremonial gift from Rimshi Dote, one of the Tibetan district governors, who is almost seven feet tall, enroute to Lhasa, the forbidden capital of Tibet. Thomas and his son, Lowell Thomas, Jr., were the 7th and 8th Americans allowed to visit that strange country which forms the basis of Episode No. 4 in the CBS television series, "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," (CBS-TV, Tuesday, February 25, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST)

HORSES WIN OKAY: Lowell Thomas and party followed the ancient and treacherous caravan route from Sikkim over the high Himalayas to get to forbidden Tibet, which is the backdrop for the fourth installment of High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be colorcast over the CBS television network Tuesday, February 25th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST. Thomas fondles his equine carrier which is most dependable form of transportation since Tibetans absolutely forbid travel by air, car, or even by carriage, or cart. As far as transportation is concerned, Tibet is a country without a wheel

AND THE RAINS CAME: Lowell Thomas and son, Lowell Thomas, Jr., take breather on perilous 24-day trek over Himalayas to the forbidden land of Tibet which serves as the theme of Episode No. 4 of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be colorcast on CBS-TV, Tuesday, February 25, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST under the sponsorship of the United Motors Service and Delco-Remy division of General Motors. The two are wearing regulation U.S. navy foul-weather gear because it rained practically all through the trip

ROYAL WELCOME: Among the first westerners permitted to penetrate the forbidden land of Tibet, Lowell Thomas, Jr. (left) and his illustrious father, Lowell Thomas, Sr. (right) received a royal welcome form the Dalai Lama, legendary ruler of the strange country which isolated itself from civilization for centuries. Here, they pose with gifts in the Dalai Lama's fantastic 1000-room castle in Lhasa, Tibet's capital, which will be highlighted in Episode No. 4 (Tibet) of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" on CBS-TV, Tuesday, February 25th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy division of General Motors

Subject files: High Adventure with Lowell Thomas (Australian Outback)

OUTBACK BACKGROUND: A good idea of the roughness of the Australian Outback terrain which is featured in the fifth edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (in color on CBS-TV, Monday, March 24th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST) can be obtained from this photo showing trucks of the Lowell Thomas expedition trying to find traveling space. Most sections of the vast desert, however, can be traversed only by camel. The Thomas troupe spent months in this forsaken land looking for the bones of the lost Australian-American explorer, Harold Bell Lasseter. The search was successful. The Lasseter story is the subject of the fifth "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" which is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy division of General Motors

Note: [press release] OUTBACK BACKGROUND: A good idea of the roughness of the Australian Outback terrain which is featured in the fifth edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (in color on CBS-TV, Monday, March 24th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST) can be obtained from this photo showing trucks of the Lowell Thomas expedition trying to find traveling space. Most sections of the vast desert, however, can be traversed only by camel. The Thomas troupe spent months in this forsaken land looking for the bones of the lost Australian-American explorer, Harold Bell Lasseter. The search was successful. The Lasseter story is the subject of the fifth "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" which is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy division of General Motors

[2 copies] LOWELL THOMAS AND AUSSIE ABORIGINE EXAMINE SACRED TRIBAL "DREAMING STONE" IN DESERT: Lowell Thomas and Nosepeg, an aborigine of Australia's Pitjinjara tribe, inspect an ancient "dreaming stone" along the trail of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television, 8:00-9:00 PM, EST) Monday, March 24. On these rocks, the history of the pre-historic tribes can be traced by aborigine medicine men. Near this spot Thomas's 26-member expedition solved the 28-year-old mystery of the disappearance of gold-hunter Harold Bell Lasseter

AUSTRALIAN ABORIGINE MAKES ANIMAL TRACKS IN RED SAND OF "HIGH ADVENTURE" TRAIL: An aborigine of the Pindabee tribe scratches animal tracks in the red sand of the Australian Outback as film director lee Robinson (wearing sun hat) watcher, during the shooting of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television, 8:00-9:00 PM EST) Monday, March 24. On the program, which travels through some of the world's most uncharted territory, Thomas and his expedition discover the long-lost grave of soldier of fortune Harold Bell Lasseter

Note: [press release] AUSTRALIAN ABORIGINE MAKES ANIMAL TRACKS IN RED SAND OF "HIGH ADVENTURE" TRAIL: An aborigine of the Pindabee tribe scratches animal tracks in the red sand of the Australian Outback as film director lee Robinson (wearing sun hat) watcher, during the shooting of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television, 8:00-9:00 PM EST) Monday, March 24. On the program, which travels through some of the world's most uncharted territory, Thomas and his expedition discover the long-lost grave of soldier of fortune Harold Bell Lasseter

ROCK AND TWO ROLLERS: Deep in Central Australia, Lowell Thomas (left) and Director Lee Robinson discuss next move in filming the fifth edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (in color, CBS-TV, Monday, March 24th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST) which deals with the hunt for the body of Harold Bell Lasseter, Australian-American explorer who was lost in 1931 while trying to relocate a fabulous gold reef in the rugged Outback country. Behind the duo is the world's largest single rock called Ayres Rock. It is 1100 feet high and over 8 miles around the base

Note: [press release] ROCK AND TWO ROLLERS: Deep in Central Australia, Lowell Thomas (left) and Director Lee Robinson discuss next move in filming the fifth edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (in color, CBS-TV, Monday, March 24th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST) which deals with the hunt for the body of Harold Bell Lasseter, Australian-American explorer who was lost in 1931 while trying to relocate a fabulous gold reef in the rugged Outback country. Behind the duo is the world's largest single rock called Ayres Rock. It is 1100 feet high and over 8 miles around the base

LOWELL THOMAS AND AUSTRALIAN DROVER SWAP YARNS ALONG "HIGH ADVENTURE" TRAIL: Lowell Thomas (1) and Matt Savage, Central Australia's oldest drover, swap yarns along the trail to "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television, 8:00-9:00 PM, EST) Monday, March 24. In the middle of the sprawling Australian continent, where cattle stations (ranches) range up to 9,000,00 acres, Thomas and a 26-member expedition trek into the untamed Outback to solve a desert mystery which had existed for 28 years-the disappearance of gold-hunter Harold Bell Lasseter

THE DEVIL YOU CARE: Lowell Thomas is entranced by a strange species of lizard called "mountain devils" while color-filming the fifth installment of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS-TV, Monday, March 24th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST) which deals with life in the desolate Outback country in Central Australia. Former themes in the "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" series, sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy division of General Motors, were New Guinea, the North pole, Africa and Tibet

END TO A 28-YEAR-OLD MYSTERY: In the middle of the vast Australian Outback, Dr. John Quinn, Lucky Harris and Lowell Thomas (left to right) inspect the remains of gold-hunter Harold Bell Lasseter during the climax of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television, 8:00-9:00 PM, EST) Monday, March 24. When Thomas and his crew found the bones of Lasseter in a lonely red-sand grave in the Petermann Range, it ended a 28-year-old mystery about the fate of the Aussie-American soldier of fortune who vanished in 1930

Subject files: High Adventure with Lowell Thomas (Tiger Hunt)

GOOD LISTENER----Lowell Thomas (right) takes some good advice from John Grisham [Jack Girsham?], who knows his way around the rugged country of northeast India, during filming in color of sixth edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" which will be televised on CBS network Saturday, April 19, from 9:00 to 10:00 p.m., EST. Grisham [Girsham?], carrying elephant rifle, was a most valued scout with the famous Merrill's Marauders during that unit's tussles with the Japanese in Burma in World War II. A hunt for wild elephants and man-eating tigers features this particular edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

Note: [press release] GOOD LISTENER----Lowell Thomas (right) takes some good advice from John Grisham [Jack Girsham?], who knows his way around the rugged country of northeast India, during filming in color of sixth edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" which will be televised on CBS network Saturday, April 19, from 9:00 to 10:00 p.m., EST. [Lowell Thomas standing with John Grisham, tiger hunter]

BUILDING A BETTER TRAP----Natives in Assam Province of northeast India are in the process of constructing huge trap for man-eating tiger that has been attacking fellow villagers. Over 500 spearmen and "beaters" participated in the hunt for the striped beast which is featured in the next edition in color of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS-TV network, Saturday, April 19, 9:00 to 10:00 p.m., EST). Other stirring sequence in the hour-long show depicts capture and training of wild elephants. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

POINTS THE WAY----Noted film director Willard Van Dyke points out next scene in action during filming of sixth episode (Tiger Hunt in India) of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (in color over CBS-TV network, Saturday, April 19, 9:00 to 10:00 p.m., EST). Lowell Thomas and his production crew spent more than three months in the jungles of Assam Province in northeast India photographing live capture of a vicious man-eating tiger by 500 natives. Also to be seen in the film is round-up of wild elephants for conversion to domestic use. Mahouts on elephants in background actually "lasso" the wild pachyderms in same fashion as Western cowboys rope steers. Van Dyke won much acclaim for his production and direction of the documentary film, "The City"

"HOLD THAT TIGER!" ; Indian spearmen (members of the Tiger Catching Society of Jamaguri) gather about a very dead tiger at the end of the trail of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (CBS Television Network, 9:00-10:00 PM, EST) Saturday, April 19.; The big cat, punctured by a dozen native spears, was reportedly the same Royal Bengal tiger which had killed 35 Indian tea plantation workers. The killings ceased after Lowell Thomas hired more than 500 native spearmen to track the cat

Thomas introduces the mad dance of the Marrakech houris is one segment of the show which is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

Subject files: High Adventure with Lowell Thomas (Alaska)

LOWELL THOMAS SHOWS ARCTIC GEAR USED IN FILMING ALASKA "HIGH ADVENTURE" ; Lowell Thomas displays some foul-weather gear used in filming the Alaska episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will have its premiere Wednesday, Oct. 8, 8:00-9:00 PM, EDT, over the CBS Television Network.; Between air trips, world traveler Thomas pauses at the New York office of Odyssey Productions, Inc., which is filming his overseas adventure episodes

Note: [press release] LOWELL THOMAS SHOWS ARCTIC GEAR USED IN FILMING ALASKA "HIGH ADVENTURE" ; Lowell Thomas displays some foul-weather gear used in filming the Alaska episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will have its premiere Wednesday, Oct. 8, 8:00-9:00 PM, EDT, over the CBS Television Network.; Between air trips, world traveler Thomas pauses at the New York office of Odyssey Productions, Inc., which is filming his overseas adventure episodes

PIQUED BY PEAK -- One of Alaska's imposing mountains is a background for Lowell Thomas as the intrepid explorer-author-producer gets ready to "shoot" scenes in full color for the initial installment of the new "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" TV series which will bow over the CBS television network on Wednesday, October 8th, from 8:00 to 9:00 p.m., Eastern Daylight Time. Entire show is devoted to the challenges and possibilities of America's newest state and last big frontier. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" is presented by the united Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

FAMILY FAREWELL - Leaving on a dangerous camera mission deep in Alaska mountains for scenes in the first episode of the new "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" series (in full color, CBS television network, Wednesday, October 8th, from 8:00 to 9:00 p.m. EDT), Lowell Thomas, Sr. (right) and son, Lowell Thomas, Jr., get go-ahead signal at base headquarters from latter's wife and 3-year old daughter, Ann. Flag is official emblem of the Explorers Club of New York. Presented by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors, four thrill-packed installments of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" will be seen during the coming fall and winter

GETS INSIDE INFO - Chiefs of the Tlingit Indians of Alaska let Lowell Thomas in on age-old secret tribal rites during production of certain scenes for the first episode (Alaska - America's Last Frontier) of the new "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" series in full color on Wednesday, October 8th, from 8:00 to 9:00 p.m., Eastern Daylight Time under the sponsorship of the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors. Before the purchase of Alaska by the United States in 1867, the Tlingits fought a bloody war with the incumbent Russians

ICY INTRODUCTION - Lowell Thomas emerges from a crevasse in Alaska's immense glacial ice pack during "shooting" of first edition of the new series of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" color films set for showing over the CBS television network Wednesday, October 8th, 8:00 to 9:00 p.m., Eastern Daylight Time. Sun glasses, special skin ointment, etc. are necessary to protect the face and eyes from dangerous infra-red rays bouncing off the glaring snow. Lowell Thomas and camera crews ranged America's newest state from Point Barrow to Juneau for the one-hour Alaskan "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which again is presented by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

HIGH FLIERS - Daring every-day escapades of fearless Alaskan bush pilots are dramatically depicted in the first edition (Alaska-America's Last Frontier) of the new "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" video series in full color over the CBS television network Wednesday, October 8th from 8:00 to 9:00 p.m., Eastern Daylight Time. Here, Lowell Thomas disembarks on the tricky Alaska ice pack from a light plane piloted by Merrill Wien, one of the best-known of the Alaskan daredevils whose exploits will make armchair adventurers sit up and take notice. Because of the lack of railroads and highways, the plane is the most used transportation vehicle nowadays in the land of the midnight sun. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

Subject files: High Adventure with Lowell Thomas (Danger Island)

DANGER FLIGHT - Lowell Thomas dons lifejacket before leaving by helicopter from the deck of the USS Point Defiance for first look at Danger Island (Puka Puka), tiny coral atoll in the South Pacific, which is the scene for the third edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" to be colorcast over the CBS television network, Monday, January 19th, from 10:00 to 11:00 p.m., EST. Later, Thomas landed on the island with 32 famous scientists to check reactions of the sun by outer space rockets during the solar eclipse of October 12th

Note: [press release] DANGER FLIGHT - Lowell Thomas dons lifejacket before leaving by helicopter from the deck of the USS Point Defiance for first look at Danger Island (Puka Puka), tiny coral atoll in the South Pacific, which is the scene for the third edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" to be colorcast over the CBS television network, Monday, January 19th, from 10:00 to 11:00 p.m., EST. Later, Thomas landed on the island with 32 famous scientists to check reactions of the sun by outer space rockets during the solar eclipse of October 12th

UNUSUAL ROLE - Lowell Thomas (back row, center) officiates as King Neptune during ceremonies initiating "pollywogs" (first-time crossers of the Equator) into "shellbacks" aboard USS Point Defiance, which carried him and 32 world-famed American scientists to remote Puka Puka, or Danger Island, in the South Seas for one of the most important projects of the International Geophysical Year. Colorful, exciting activities on the island are main feature of the third installment of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" coming to TV screens in full color over the CBS network Monday, January 19th, from 10:00 to 11:00 p.m., EST. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

Note: [press release] UNUSUAL ROLE - Lowell Thomas (back row, center) officiates as King Neptune during ceremonies initiating "pollywogs" (first-time crossers of the Equator) into "shellbacks" aboard USS Point Defiance, which carried him and 32 world-famed American scientists to remote Puka Puka, or Danger Island, in the South Seas for one of the most important projects of the International Geophysical Year. Colorful, exciting activities on the island are main feature of the third installment of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" coming to TV screens in full color over the CBS network Monday, January 19th, from 10:00 to 11:00 p.m., EST. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

SHIP TO SHORE - On board USS Point Defiance in the South Seas, preparatory to debarking to the lonely isle of Puka Puka, or Danger Island, Lowell Thomas (r.) confers with Dr. Friedman, one of the leaders of the 32-man Naval Research Laboratory scientific expedition, which used the island as headquarters to study the sun during the October 12th solar eclipse. Activities of the scientists on this by-passed coral atoll inhabited by a few hundred Polynesians, who have had little or no previous contact with the outer world, make for dramatic contrast in the third edition in color of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be telecast over the CBS-TV network, Monday, January 19th, from 10:00-11:00 p.m., EST

Note: [press release] SHIP TO SHORE - On board USS Point Defiance in the South Seas, preparatory to debarking to the lonely isle of Puka Puka, or Danger Island, Lowell Thomas (r.) confers with Dr. Friedman, one of the leaders of the 32-man Naval Research Laboratory scientific expedition, which used the island as headquarters to study the sun during the October 12th solar eclipse. Activities of the scientists on this by-passed coral atoll inhabited by a few hundred Polynesians, who have had little or no previous contact with the outer world, make for dramatic contrast in the third edition in color of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be telecast over the CBS-TV network, Monday, January 19th, from 10:00-11:00 p.m., EST

HOWDY, FOLKS - Lowell Thomas waves "howdy" while standing beside a Nike-Asp rocket on board the USS Point Defiance which transported the explorer and 32 scientists to the lonely isle of Puka Puka, or Danger Island, in the South Seas, scene of the third edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" to be colorcast over the CBS-TV network Monday, January 19th, 10:00-11:00 p.m., EST under the auspices of the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors. Puka Puka, directly in the path of the October 12th solar eclipse, was used by the scientists as headquarters to study the sun under eclipse conditions as one of the most important projects of the International Geophysical Year. The "Sadie Thompson" rocket was one of the six fired 150 miles into outer space to observe the sun from that vantage point during the eclipse totality. Besides the activity on Danger Island, Samoa, Tahiti and other South Sea spots are featured in the forthcoming "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas"

DANGER ISLAND HEADQUARTERS - This is the camp set up for 32 American scientists by the U. S. Navy on Puka Puka, or Danger Island, in the uncharted South Seas, scene of the third installment of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (in color, CBS-TV, Monday, January 19th, 10:00-11:00 p.m., EST). One of the most important projects of the International Geophysical Year, scientists used jet-age instruments, including rockets launched 150 miles into outer space, to record activities of the sun during the October 12th eclipse. Navy frogmen were forced to blast a channel through dangerous reef to land supplies on the seldom-visited island. This and other dramatic incidents are featured in the "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" show, which is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

CONFERENCE, SOUTH SEAS STYLE - Against the backdrop of a bungalow built of packing cases on the little coral atoll of Puka Puka, or Danger Island, in the remote South Seas, Lowell Thomas (r.) holds a production conference concerning the third episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (in color, CBS-TV, Monday, January 19th, 10:00-11:00 p.m., EST) with Technicians (l. to r.) Bert Gerard, Roger Bulov and Director Bob Young. Crew were on the island to photograph activities of 32 American scientists, transported there by U. S. Naval Research Laboratory to study sun rays, sun flares, sun spots, etc. during the October 12th eclipse. Project was considered one of the most important of the International Geophysical Year

EXOTIC BELLE - "Whiskey Johnnie" (that's her real name) Frisbie, half-native daughter of the legendary South Seas author, Rober Dean Frisbie, performs in an Hawaiian night club for opening scenes in the third episode of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (in color, CBS-TV, Monday, January 19th, 10:00-11:00 p.m., EST). Thomas stopped off to interview "Whiskey Johnnie" about the little, unknown island of Puka Puka, or Danger Island, in the South Seas, where she was born and which is the backdrop for the next "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" show. The island, virtually cut off from civilization for centuries because its dangerous reef barred all vessels became the headquarters of a group of scientists from the U.S., transported there by the U. S. Navy to gather valuable knowledge about the sun during the October 12th eclipse. Six Nike-asp rockets launched 150 miles into space used in the observations. Titled "Danger Island," the Thomas one-hour film in color will highlight this and other dramatic events on the island during the IGY project. "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

Subject files: High Adventure with Lowell Thomas (From the Persian Gulf to Zanzibar)

THEY GO TO HIS HEAD - Lowell Thomas, distinguished explorer and commentator whose next "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" TV show will be beamed over the CBS Television network on Friday, March 27th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST, is a hat collector. During his myriad wanderings around the world, Thomas has amassed an amazing collection of strange and exotic headgear which is stored in a special building on his estate near Pawling, N. Y. Thomas is shown here with a small part of his collection. Although he could get heady making a choice from the hundreds of hats he has on hand, Lowell, prefers the light gray Texas-type headpiece shown on the far right

ENDED RIGHT HERE - Back in the United States, Lowell Thomas points out the exotic island of Zanzibar, final port of call on a 3,500-mile ocean trip in an ancient Arabian dhow along the Arabian and East African coasts from Bahrein on the Persian Gulf. The exciting fourth installment of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" will be colorcast over the CBS television network Friday, March 27th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST, under the sponsorship of the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors. It took the sail-driven dhow a month to make the voyage. Besides life on the dhow, the next "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" also will display other thrill-packed sequences such as a falcon hunt in southern Arabia, a pearl diving expedition in the Persian Gulf, a turtle hunt along Africa's east coast and a novel bullfight in Zanzibar where the bull always wins!

TOPS ANYTHING FOR STYLE - Lowell Thomas, whose next "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" show will be seen in full color over the CBS television network Friday, March 27, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST, has one of the world's finest collection of hats garnered during his travels to every nook and cranny of the glove. Thomas says that one of the most becoming hats on all men is this Persian lamb headgear which was given to him by one of the fierce tribal chiefs in the mountainous country of Afghanistan

A DAY WITH DAY - On a month-long, 3,500-mile trip by native dhow from the Persian Gulf to Zanzibar, theme of the fourth installment of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (in full color, CBS-TV network, Friday, March 27th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST), Thomas stops off at the forbidden port of Mukalla on the South Arabian coast to chat with Wendy Day, the daughter of famed Clarence ("Life with Father" ) Day, who is the only American woman of four white women in residence there. Miss Day, who is married to a British fisheries officer, will be seen in one of the sequences of the March 27th shows, which is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

Note: [press release] A DAY WITH DAY - On a month-long, 3,500-mile trip by native dhow from the Persian Gulf to Zanzibar, theme of the fourth installment of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" (in full color, CBS-TV network, Friday, March 27th, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST), Thomas stops off at the forbidden port of Mukalla on the South Arabian coast to chat with Wendy Day, the daughter of famed Clarence ("Life with Father" ) Day, who is the only American woman of four white women in residence there. DHOW-AGER OF THE SEA - Ancient Arabian sailing vessel, or dhow, is tied up in the strange port of Mukalla in Southern Arabia while Lowell Thomas and his production crew photographed scenes for the fourth edition of "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which will be beamed over the CBS-TV network Friday, March 27, 8:00-9:00 p.m., EST. Following the northwest monsoon trade winds, the dhow, which is one of the silent stars of the March 27th show, made the 3,500-mile trip from Bahrein on the Persian Gulf to the spice island of Zanzibar off Africa's east coast in a month. Many strange ports of call visited by the dhow were covered by the Thomas cameramen and will be seen in the next "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas," which is sponsored by the United Motors System and Delco-Remy Division of General Motors

Dear Ed Heffron, Three of these pictures were taken on an expedition in Australia. The old boy with the white beard and the heavy eyebrows is an Australian Drover. He was a well known character in the Australian Outback. Which I had a copy of that one. I've forgotten what they call the little animals on my arm. They actually look like dragons, and evidently are rather rare. We encountered them deep in the interior of Australia when we were on an expedition. The man chatting with me in the picture where I'm sitting on the front of a Land Rover, is an Australian film producer named Lee Robinson who was directing the making of our film. Behind us is what the Australians consider one of the wonders of the world, Ayers Rock. They say it is the largest single rock in the world and is several miles in circumference. The one with the young lady was made in a palace in the Atlas Mountains, in Morocco. And the one where I'm sitting at a table with a mask beside me was made in what was known as the Belgian Congo on the shores of Lake Albert. Sincerely, Lowell Thomas; P.S. All the pictures were probably all taken in 1958

Subject files: King Hussein of Jordan

Toastmaster Lowell Thomas, who needs no introduction to any audience, presents His Majesty, King Hussein of Jordan to an audience of nearly a thousand people at a dinner given by Near East Foundation in honor of the Jordanian Monarch. The Foundation has been engaged with the Jordanian government in a cooperative program of technical assistance and community development

Note: Toastmaster Lowell Thomas, who needs no introduction to any audience, presents His Majesty, King Hussein of Jordan to an audience of nearly a thousand people at a dinner given by Near East Foundation in honor of the Jordanian Monarch. The Foundation has been engaged with the Jordanian government in a cooperative program of technical assistance and community development
Caption: To my very good friend Lowell Thomas, wish very great wishes [?] signed King Hussein 29.6.64
Toastmaster Lowell Thomas and Dinner Chairman Mrs. Robert Howe Baldwin engage His Majesty, King Hussein, in conversation as the receiving line is forming
